prompt.p: A full blood count and blood film are used to investigate iron deficiency anaemia.
What type of cell is not seen in a blood film for iron deficiency?

modalFeedback.p: Option D (Reed-Sternberg) is Correct. Reed-Sternberg cells are not seen in a blood film for iron deficiency.

tr.td: low red cell indices, mean cell volume and mean corpuscular haemoglobin

A reduced rate of haemoglobin synthesis due to lack of precursors results in more cell division time as red cells develop until they reach the critical haemoglobin concentration - resulting in smaller cells. Lower levels of haemoglobin in the cells make them appear pale
unbalanced surface membrane to cytoplasmic volume due to reduced haemoglobin
decreased cytoplasmic volume due to reduced haemoglobin
Low serum ferritin. Normal levels do not exclude iron deficiency as ferritin is an acute phase protein that may be raised for other reasons
more free transferrin available to bind to iron

modalFeedback.p:
Table 12.10 Laboratory findings in iron deficiency.
Taken from: Naish et al: Basic Medical Sciences 1E
Option A (Hypochromic) is Incorrect. Hypochromic cells are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.
Option B (Microcytic) is Incorrect. Microcytic cells are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.
Option C (Pencil) is Incorrect. Pencil cells are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.
Option E (Target) is Incorrect. Target calls are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.
Option D (Reed-Sternberg) is Correct. Reed-Sternberg cells are not seen in a blood film for iron deficiency.
